data.text: For the same money, you may also look at Kona Lana'l. A bit better geometry for trail riding with its' 68HT angle with the same bits and pieces. The Salsa rangefinder has a better drivetrain and slightly more suspension travel in the roughly the same price range. It is hard for any bike to do everything well so it is often helpful to share what you are wanting from a bike with your LBS. Availability is going to be something to consider as well. Keep your options open for a steel frame for durability and comfort on long rides. Maybe take a look at the Surly Bridgeclub. A bit more money and the geometry is not as aggressive for trail riding, but the frame is made for a lifetime of service and has plenty of rack connections for touring. If your budget allows, the options expand greatly as price goes up.

data.text:
Nothing wrong with the Marlin - just depends what you want to do with it. The fork is the weak point - not for serious mountain biking but fine for decent single-track. If that's your budget, it's fine. Decathlon makes some good value bikes but availability is an issue these days. https://www.decathlon.co.uk/p/27-5-inch-mountain-bike-rockrider-st-900/_/R-p-301098?mc=8500763&c=GREY

data.text: I'm a mountain bike tour operator , we use 30 trek marlin 6, since 2017, and very satisfied, all our guests love them . We cycled them 1000s of miles from Myanmar to Singapore, and the remotest mountain areas in Myanmar and Thailand, as well as on the roads and streets of the cities in Myanmar. Definitely recommend. Not high end or ultra light. but very sturdy and reliable. And no, you definitely do not need a rear suspension when doing normal rides ...
